data.title: Vally Worth in Ein Walzertraum
data.meta_description: For Greg! Austrian postcard, no. 1012, sent by mail in 1908. Rotophot - S. Blueh, Wien. Photo: L. (Ludwig) Gutmann, Wien, 1907. Vally Worth (here Vally Wordt) in the original stage production of 'Ein Walzertraum' (1907). Caption: "I weiss net, i weiss net, Ob i traum 'oder wach'! Was haben S'gesagt, was haben S'gesagt? Dass i net lach'!" ("I don't know, I don't know, Whether I'm dreaming or awake What did you say, what did you say? That I'm not laughing!") 'Ein Walzertraum' (A Waltz Dream) is an operetta by Oscar Straus with a German libretto by Leopold Jacobson and Felix Dörmann, based on the novella 'Nux, der Prinzgemahl' (Nux, the Prince Consort) by Hans Müller-Einigen from his 1905 book 'Buch der Abenteuer' (Book of Adventures). The young Jacobson presented Straus with a libretto for 'Ein Walzertraum' at a coffee house in the Vienna Prater in 1906. Straus was inspired by the text and completed the work within 12 months for its premiere in the spring of 1907 at the Carltheater in Vienna. Vally Worth (on the card written as Wordt) played the role of Annerl, a member of the Ladies' band. Following the success of 'Ein Walzertraum' in Vienna, productions of the work, under the name 'A Waltz Dream', were mounted in English for premieres in 1908 at the Chestnut Street Opera House in Philadelphia, in New York City at the now-demolished Broadway Theatre, and in London at the Hicks Theatre, starring Gertie Millar, W. H. Berry and later Robert Evett, Jessie Broughton and Arthur Williams. Lily Elsie and Amy Evans starred in the 1911 revival at Daly's Theatre. The international success of the operetta exceeded Straus's expectations. In 1907, there was already a short film version, Ein Walzertraum (1907) with Fritz Werner. According to IMDb, it was the first film made and shown in Austria. Other film versions of the operetta include the Hungarian film Varázskeringő/Magic Waltz (Michael Curtiz, 1918) with Victor Varconi, the German film Ein Walzer Traum/A Waltz Dream (Ludwig Berger, 1925) with Willy Fritsch, Mady Christians und Xenia Desni, and The Smiling Lieutenant (Ernst Lubitsch, 1931), starring Maurice Chevalier and Claudette Colbert. Sources: Wikipedia (English and German) and IMDb. And, please check out our blog European Film Star Postcards.
data.text:
For Greg!

Austrian postcard, no. 1012, sent by mail in 1908. Rotophot - S. Blueh, Wien. Photo: L. (Ludwig) Gutmann, Wien, 1907. Vally Worth (here Vally Wordt) in the original stage production of 'Ein Walzertraum' (1907). Caption:

"I weiss net, i weiss net,

Ob i traum 'oder wach'!

Was haben S'gesagt, was haben S'gesagt?

Dass i net lach'!"

("I don't know, I don't know,

Whether I'm dreaming or awake

What did you say, what did you say?

That I'm not laughing!")

'Ein Walzertraum' (A Waltz Dream) is an operetta by Oscar Straus with a German libretto by Leopold Jacobson and Felix Dörmann, based on the novella 'Nux, der Prinzgemahl' (Nux, the Prince Consort) by Hans Müller-Einigen from his 1905 book 'Buch der Abenteuer' (Book of Adventures). The young Jacobson presented Straus with a libretto for 'Ein Walzertraum' at a coffee house in the Vienna Prater in 1906. Straus was inspired by the text and completed the work within 12 months for its premiere in the spring of 1907 at the Carltheater in Vienna. Vally Worth (on the card written as Wordt) played the role of Annerl, a member of the Ladies' band.

Following the success of 'Ein Walzertraum' in Vienna, productions of the work, under the name 'A Waltz Dream', were mounted in English for premieres in 1908 at the Chestnut Street Opera House in Philadelphia, in New York City at the now-demolished Broadway Theatre, and in London at the Hicks Theatre, starring Gertie Millar, W. H. Berry and later Robert Evett, Jessie Broughton and Arthur Williams. Lily Elsie and Amy Evans starred in the 1911 revival at Daly's Theatre. The international success of the operetta exceeded Straus's expectations. In 1907, there was already a short film version, Ein Walzertraum (1907) with Fritz Werner. According to IMDb, it was the first film made and shown in Austria. Other film versions of the operetta include the Hungarian film Varázskeringő/Magic Waltz (Michael Curtiz, 1918) with Victor Varconi, the German film Ein Walzer Traum/A Waltz Dream (Ludwig Berger, 1925) with Willy Fritsch, Mady Christians und Xenia Desni, and The Smiling Lieutenant (Ernst Lubitsch, 1931), starring Maurice Chevalier and Claudette Colbert.

Sources: Wikipedia (English and German) and IMDb.
